title: 107_s1735
content:
The National Commission on Threats to the Homeland and United States National Security (referred to as the "Commission") is established. The composition of the Commission is outlined. The National Commission on Threats to the Homeland and United States National Security is composed of six members appointed by various officials, including the President, Senate Majority Leader, Senate Minority Leader, Speaker of the House, and House Minority Leader. Members must be distinguished Americans with senior-level experience in federal government agencies. The Commission elects a Chairman from its members. The National Commission on Threats to the Homeland and United States National Security elects a Chairman from among its members. A majority of members constitute a quorum. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Meetings are called by the Chairman or a majority of members. Members should be appointed within 30 days of the Act's enactment. The purpose of the National Commission on Threats to the Homeland and United States National Security is outlined in Section 3. The Commission will evaluate threats to US national security post-9/11 to help prioritize the national budget and government organization. It will assess various threats, considering analyses from different entities like the US Commission on National Security/21st Century and the Department of Energy Russia Task Force. The Advisory Panel will make recommendations to prioritize threats to US national security, considering the likelihood and potential damage of attacks, as well as current capabilities to counter and respond to such threats. SEC. 4. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and utilize postal, printing, and binding services as needed to fulfill its responsibilities under this Act. The Commission operates under the same conditions as other federal agencies. The Commission operates under the same conditions as other federal agencies. SEC. 5. STAFF OF THE COMMISSION. The Chairman of the Commission has the authority to appoint a staff director and additional personnel without following standard government appointment procedures. The staff director must come from private life and their pay can be determined by the Chairman without adhering to standard pay regulations, with a maximum pay rate set at level V of the Executive Schedule. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint staff without standard procedures, with pay up to level V of the Executive Schedule. Government personnel can be detailed to assist the Commission, and temporary services can be procured at specified rates. Administrative and support services are overseen by the Administrator. The Administrator of General Services provides administrative and support services to the Commission on a non-reimbursable basis as requested. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may receive compensation not exceeding the daily equivalent of level V of the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses at authorized rates. SEC. 7. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. SEC. 7. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. The US Government will provide security clearances to Commission members and staff promptly, following existing procedures. Access to classified information will only be granted to those who qualify for such clearance. SEC. 8. REPORTS.

    The Commission must submit an interim report within 180 days of the Act's enactment and a final report by September 11, 2002, detailing its activities and recommendations. 

SEC. 9. FUNDING.

    Funds from the Act of September 18, 2001, will be used to support this Act.

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report required by section 8(b), during which it may conclude its activities and disseminate the report.
